awd_titl_txt: IDR: Rapid, three-dimensional microscopy of cell-cell interactions in suspension
awd_abstract_narration:
1014838
Huser

This project will develop a unique state-of-the-art technology to obtain rapid three-dimensional maps of the function and structure of an extremely important class of cells: immune cells. It will utilize rapid optical imaging at high spatial and temporal resolution of suspension cells in their most natural environment (i.e. freely suspended without substrates present). This new instrument will allow one to measure and record physiological changes in cells in 3 dimensions at millisecond time scales. This system will lead to significant advancement in multiple scientific disciplines, i.e. cellular imaging, cell biology, immunology, virology, etc. by enabling the quantitative assessment of cellular organization and reorganization due to changes in their environment at the sub-cellular level in real-time. This novel instrumentation will significantly enhance the ability to quantify rapid cellular processes of suspended immune cells at the molecular level, something that is not possible with current technology. It will enable the study cellular interactions with a great degree of control by enabling one to manipulate and increase the number of cellular interactions and follow them dynamically.

Project Outcomes Report for Project Award ID: 1014838

Title: "IDR: Rapid, three-dimensional microscopy of cell-cell interactions in suspension"

 

Optical microscopy, and fluorescence microscopy in particular, is one the most widely used methods for visualizing cells and cellular structures in the life sciences. This is primarily due to its ease of use, relatively low cost, and the wide choice of available optical contrast methods. In order to obtain high quality optical images of cells and tissue, however, samples typically have to be placed on a suitable substrate with well-characterized optical properties (typically glass cover slips of defined thickness). A number of cells of extremely high importance or interest, i.e. immune cells and bacterial cells, however, are not adherent or are easily changed when forced onto a surface (i.e. they will behave differently than in suspension). In this project we have developed a high speed and high resolution confocal fluorescence microscope system that allow us to obtain three-dimensional images of non-adherent cells in suspension. The cells are held by optical tweezers (similar to a "tractor beam" in Star Trek) and can be manipulated at will, brought in close proximity, and stimulated - all in the absence of an interfering substrate. This unique combination of optical instruments enables the unrestricted handling of samples, even infectious samples, by optical forces, while continuously obtaining high resolution three-dimensional images of the samples. We have demonstrated the unique capabilities of this system by studying the shape of red blood cells in suspension, which revealed that their natural state is a bowl-like shape rather than the disc-like shape shown in most text books. We have also studied infected white blood cells during their manipulation by optical tweezers, and we have used this system to determine the distribution of the genome contained within bacterial cells with a resolution of less than 100 nm while the cells are held by optical tweezers. The new technology that we developed in this project now permits us to accomplish rapid optical imaging at high spatial and temporal resolution of cells in their most natural environment (i.e. freely suspended in solution). It allow us to measure and record changes in cell shape and health status in all dimensions at millisecond time scales. We have presented the results of this work at a number of scientific workshops, in educational short courses on novel optical technology, in the form of peer-reviewed publications, and we have disseminated our novel views of living cells in the form of movies and 3D renderings, which provide a significantly easier way to promote the understanding of basic concepts to students and the general public.
